awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Spectra of Linear Differential Operators and Turbulence in Integrable Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Nonlinear evolution equations, also known as soliton equations, are used to model a wide variety of physical systems, such as ocean waves or fiber optic communications. Many such equations, for example the Korteweg-de Vries (KdV) equation for waves in shallow water, have the exciting feature that many of their solutions can be given exactly by an explicit formula. This allows one to develop a precise understanding of the underlying physical processes. However, the range of conditions for which exact solutions are currently known is restrictive, inhibiting the use of such solutions in real-world applications. This project aims to find larger families of exact solutions to soliton equations, and use these solutions to develop statistical theories of the corresponding physical systems. 
  
The main goal of the project is to construct and study new families of solutions of soliton equations such as KdV, Nonlinear Schrödinger, and Kadomtsev-Petviashvili. These solutions are obtained as limits of multisoliton solutions, and are bounded and non-decreasing at infinity. They are described by a Riemann-Hilbert problem and can be efficiently computed numerically. The first goal is a rigorous mathematical description of these new solutions. The PIs will investigate to what extent these solutions solve the initial value problem for KdV and related systems. They will study spectral properties of the associated linear operators and construct non-periodic one-dimensional ideal conductors. Finally, the PIs will develop a statistical theory of integrable turbulence for KdV and other soliton equations.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of our project has been to construct a new broad class of solutions to partial differential equations (PDEs) integrable by means of the inverse  scattering transform. But what is the significance of this problem from practical point of view? In modern times, many of us rely on the technology that allows fast communication all over the world. At the core of transatlantic communications are fiber optic lines that allow information transport between continents. The communication is achieved by sending trains of bits, that are represented by periodic electromagnetic pulses. However, a pulse that exits a fiber optic cable is not identical to the pulse that entered the fiber at the origin. The pulse may change it properties through effects of dispersion and nonlinear effects inherent to the fiber material. The evolution of a pulse in fiber is described by the nonlinear Schroedinger equation (NLSE), and it happens to be one of the PDEs integrable by the inverse scattering transform.

  The NLSE has been a subject of extensive studies, yet there are many open questions that still remain. We have constructed a family of solutions of NLSE, or potentials, that are bounded, non-periodic and yet not vanishing. An optical fiber of length of one thousand kilometers contains no less than 10 billion optical pulses, and thus may be considered as a bounded, non-vanishing and non-periodic potential, or a primitive potential. We developed a technique for finding primitive potentials by means of solving an auxiliary problem, that is related to NLSE by the so-called inverse scattering transform. We constructed these solutions numerically and generalized this approach to other integrable systems. The technique developed within the framework of this project has been generalized to solutions of KdV and KP equations for water waves. In addition we found clues that indicate of a possibility of integrating the 2D Euler equations with a free surface.

  Moreover, the results of present project lay the foundation for the study of turbulence in integrable systems, a new field of research that is relevant for many systems described by PDEs solvable by means of the inverse scattering transform. The present project contributed to support of graduate students, across several universities, publication of results in peer-reviewed journals and
dissemination of results at conferences. The overall goals of the proposed project have been completed successfully, and new directions of research have been found.
